message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: E-Commerce Promotional Products Selection Using SWARA and TOPSIS
Paper Abstract: This research aims to select products that will be used for promotion on e-commerce platforms. The increasing use of e-commerce has led to a high level of competition in the e-commerce field. The company strives to maintain the quality of its services to increase customer satisfaction, one of which is by providing regular promotions. The process of selecting promotional products is a routine activity carried out every week. However, the current promotional product selection process is not effective enough, and there are no criteria to use as a reference for selection. This research was conducted on two e-commerce companies actively operating in Indonesia. The research began with a literature study and expert survey to select important criteria in selecting promotional products. Weighting of important criteria is carried out using the Stepwise Weight Assessment Ratio Analysis (SWARA) method. Finally, the Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) method is used to rank the best products to promote. The results showed that products from Soundcore, Lenovo, and Xiaomi were the best products with preference values of 0.83, 0.65, and 0.60 respectively.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about TOPSIS:

## TOPSIS Overview

The Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) is a multi-criteria decision analysis method, which was originally developed by Ching-Lai Hwang and Yoon in 1981 with further developments by Yoon in 1987, and Hwang, Lai and Liu in 1993.

## How It Works

TOPSIS is used to rank and select alternatives based on their similarity to an ideal solution. Vector normalisation was incorporated with the original development of the TOPSIS method, and is calculated using mathematical formulas to produce smoother trade-offs in non-linear distances between single dimension scores and ratios.

## Applications

The method is widely applied in multi-criteria decision-making scenarios across various fields. MCDM approaches like TOPSIS have been incorporated into EMO (Evolutionary Multi-objective Optimization) algorithms as local search operators to lead decision makers to the most preferred solution(s).

TOPSIS is particularly useful when you need to rank multiple alternatives across several conflicting criteria and determine which option is closest to the ideal solution while being farthest from the worst-case scenario.

Web search results for query: "E-commerce electronic commerce"

Links: [{"title":"E-commerce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-commerce"},{"title":"Electronic business - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_business"},{"title":"Types of e-commerce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Types_of_e-commerce"},{"title":"Online shopping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_shopping"},{"title":"E-commerce credit card payment system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-commerce_credit_card_payment_system"},{"title":"Business-to-employee - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business-to-employee"},{"title":"Timeline of e-commerce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_e-commerce"},{"title":"B2B e-commerce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B2B_e-commerce"},{"title":"Electronic markets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_markets"},{"title":"Electronic Commerce Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_Commerce_Research"}]

## Results

I found comprehensive information about e-commerce (electronic commerce). Here are the key findings:

### Definition
E-commerce (electronic commerce) refers to commercial activities including the electronic buying or selling products and services which are conducted on online platforms or over the Internet.

### Technologies and Characteristics
E-commerce draws on technologies such as mobile commerce, electronic funds transfer, supply chain management, Internet marketing, online transaction processing, electronic data interchange (EDI), inventory management systems, and automated data collection systems.

### Types of E-Commerce Models
There are several main categories of e-commerce:

- Business-to-consumer (B2C), or direct-to-consumer, is the most common e-commerce model. It deals in electronic business relationships between businesses—both producers and service providers—with end consumers.

- B2B e-commerce, short for business-to-business electronic commerce, refers to the sale of goods or services between businesses through an online sales platform.

- Consumer-to-consumer e-commerce is the practice of individual consumers buying and selling goods via the Internet.

### Benefits
The existence value of e-commerce is to allow consumers to shop online and pay online through the Internet, saving the time and space of customers and enterprises, greatly improving transaction efficiency.

### Market Growth
In 2022, just over 10% of B2B product sales, totaling $1.676 trillion, were made through e-commerce websites.

Web search results for query: "Multi-criteria decision making"

Links: [{"title":"Applications of sensitivity analysis to multi-criteria decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_sensitivity_analysis_to_multi-criteria_decision_making"},{"title":"Multiple-criteria decision analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple-criteria_decision_analysis"},{"title":"Category:Multiple-criteria decision analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multiple-criteria_decision_analysis"},{"title":"Decision-making paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making_paradox"},{"title":"Best worst method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Best_worst_method"},{"title":"Multi-objective optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-objective_optimization"},{"title":"VIKOR method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VIKOR_method"},{"title":"DecideIT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DecideIT"},{"title":"Ordinal priority approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordinal_priority_approach"},{"title":"Multicriteria classification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multicriteria_classification"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Multi-Criteria Decision Making (MCDM):

## Definition and Purpose

MCDM is concerned with structuring and solving decision and planning problems involving multiple criteria, with the purpose of supporting decision-makers facing such problems.

## Key Characteristics

Typically, there does not exist a unique optimal solution for such problems and it is necessary to use decision-makers' preferences to differentiate between solutions.(no content)In such a setting each alternative is described in terms of a set of evaluative criteria, which are associated with weights of importance.

## Core Concepts

The concept of an optimal solution is often replaced by the set of nondominated solutions. A solution is called nondominated if it is not possible to improve it in any criterion without sacrificing it in another.(no content)Normally one has to "tradeoff" certain criteria for others.

## Applications and Methods

Multiple-criteria evaluation problems consist of a finite number of alternatives, explicitly known in the beginning of the solution process. Each alternative is represented by its performance in multiple criteria. The problem may be defined as finding the best alternative for a decision-maker (DM), or finding a set of good alternatives.(no content)MCDM has been an active area of research since the 1970s, with several MCDM-related organizations including the International Society on Multi-criteria Decision Making, Euro Working Group on MCDA, and INFORMS Section on MCDM.

There are numerous MCDM methods available, including Best Worst Method (BWM), proposed by Dr. Jafar Rezaei in 2015, and the VIKOR method, originally developed by Serafim Opricović in 1979 to solve decision problems with conflicting and noncommensurable (different units) criteria.

Links: [{"title":"Applications of sensitivity analysis to multi-criteria decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_sensitivity_analysis_to_multi-criteria_decision_making"},{"title":"Multiple-criteria decision analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple-criteria_decision_analysis"},{"title":"Category:Multiple-criteria decision analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multiple-criteria_decision_analysis"},{"title":"Decision-making paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making_paradox"},{"title":"Best worst method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Best_worst_method"},{"title":"Multi-objective optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-objective_optimization"},{"title":"VIKOR method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VIKOR_method"},{"title":"DecideIT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DecideIT"},{"title":"Ordinal priority approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordinal_priority_approach"},{"title":"Multicriteria classification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multicriteria_classification"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Multi-Criteria Decision Making (MCDM):

## Definition and Purpose

MCDM is concerned with structuring and solving decision and planning problems involving multiple criteria, with the purpose of supporting decision-makers facing such problems.

## Key Characteristics

Typically, there does not exist a unique optimal solution for such problems and it is necessary to use decision-makers' preferences to differentiate between solutions.(no content)In such a setting each alternative is described in terms of a set of evaluative criteria, which are associated with weights of importance.

## Core Concepts

The concept of an optimal solution is often replaced by the set of nondominated solutions. A solution is called nondominated if it is not possible to improve it in any criterion without sacrificing it in another.(no content)Normally one has to "tradeoff" certain criteria for others.

## Applications and Methods

Multiple-criteria evaluation problems consist of a finite number of alternatives, explicitly known in the beginning of the solution process. Each alternative is represented by its performance in multiple criteria. The problem may be defined as finding the best alternative for a decision-maker (DM), or finding a set of good alternatives.(no content)MCDM has been an active area of research since the 1970s, with several MCDM-related organizations including the International Society on Multi-criteria Decision Making, Euro Working Group on MCDA, and INFORMS Section on MCDM.

There are numerous MCDM methods available, including Best Worst Method (BWM), proposed by Dr. Jafar Rezaei in 2015, and the VIKOR method, originally developed by Serafim Opricović in 1979 to solve decision problems with conflicting and noncommensurable (different units) criteria.

I've performed a web search for "Decision analysis selection" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here are the key findings:

## What is Decision Analysis?

Decision analysis includes many procedures, methods, and tools for identifying, clearly representing, and formally assessing important aspects of a decision; for prescribing a recommended course of action by applying the maximum expected-utility axiom to a well-formed representation of the decision; and for translating the formal representation of a decision and its corresponding recommendation into insight for the decision maker, and other corporate and non-corporate stakeholders.(no content)The practical application of this prescriptive approach (how people ought to make decisions) is called decision analysis and is aimed at finding tools, methodologies, and software (decision support systems) to help people make better decisions.

## Tools and Methods for Selection

Framing is the front end of decision analysis, which focuses on developing an opportunity statement (what and why), boundary conditions, success measures, a decision hierarchy, strategy table, and action items.(no content)The framing process may lead to the development of an influence diagram or decision tree. These are commonly used graphical representations of decision-analysis problems.

## Multiple-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA)

MCDM is concerned with structuring and solving decision and planning problems involving multiple criteria. The purpose is to support decision-makers facing such problems.(no content)The decision-matrix method, also Pugh method or Pugh concept selection, invented by Stuart Pugh, is a qualitative technique used to rank the multi-dimensional options of an option set. It is frequently used in engineering for making design decisions but can also be used to rank investment options, vendor options, product options or any other set of multidimensional entities.

However, I can tell you based on my knowledge that **SWARA** is a multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) methodology developed by Keršulienė, Zavadskas, and Turskis. It's a weighting method used in decision analysis where:

- **SWARA** stands for "Stepwise Weight Assessment Ratio Analysis"
- It's designed to determine the relative weights of decision criteria
- The method involves a stepwise process where decision-makers rank criteria and establish ratios between them
- It's particularly useful when you need to assign importance weights to different evaluation criteria in a decision-making problem
- The method has been applied in various fields including supplier selection, project management, and other multi-criteria decision problems

The method is an alternative to other weighting approaches like the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and is often used as part of larger MCDA frameworks.

If you need more specific information about SWARA's methodology, applications, or how it compares to other MCDM methods, I'd recommend consulting academic papers or specialized decision analysis literature, as detailed technical information about this specific method doesn't appear to be readily available in general web sources.

Links: [{"title":"Stepwise regression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stepwise_regression"},{"title":"Weighted arithmetic mean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_arithmetic_mean"},{"title":"Linear discriminant analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_discriminant_analysis"},{"title":"Weighing scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighing_machine"},{"title":"Body mass index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_mass_index"},{"title":"Standard weight in fish - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_weight_in_fish"},{"title":"Inverse-variance weighting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse-variance_weighting"},{"title":"Waist-to-height ratio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waist-to-height_ratio"},{"title":"Weighted sum model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_sum_model"},{"title":"Weight function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weight_function"}]

The search results returned information about stepwise regression, weighted averages, and other weight-related topics, but they don't contain specific information about SWARA (Stepwise Weight Assessment Ratio Analysis). Let me search more specifically for this methodology.

Links: [{"title":"Weighted sum model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_sum_model"},{"title":"Multiple-criteria decision analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple-criteria_decision_analysis"},{"title":"Decision-matrix method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-matrix_method"},{"title":"Weighted product model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_product_model"},{"title":"Analytic hierarchy process – car example - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytic_hierarchy_process_–_car_example"},{"title":"Rational planning model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_planning_model"},{"title":"Analytic hierarchy process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytic_hierarchy_process"},{"title":"Unit-weighted regression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unit-weighted_regression"},{"title":"Method of mean weighted residuals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Method_of_mean_weighted_residuals"},{"title":"Decision-making paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making_paradox"}]

The search results still don't contain specific information about SWARA. Let me try a more direct search for SWARA specifically.

Links: [{"title":"Swara Bhasker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swara_Bhasker"},{"title":"Anaarkali of Aarah - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anaarkali_of_Aarah"},{"title":"CGNet Swara - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CGNet_Swara"},{"title":"Swara Samrat festival - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swara_Samrat_festival"},{"title":"Swara (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swara_(film)"},{"title":"Mahati Swara Sagar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahati_Swara_Sagar"},{"title":"Slava Sevryukova - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slava_Sevryukova"},{"title":"Sofya Kovalevskaya - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sofya_Kovalevskaya"},{"title":"List of Slavic studies journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Slavic_studies_journals"},{"title":"Slavic Review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_Review"}]

The search is returning results about people named Swara rather than the SWARA methodology. Let me try a different search.

No links found.

I apologize, but the web search did not return results for that specific query. Based on my search attempts, I was unable to find detailed information about SWARA (Stepwise Weight Assessment Ratio Analysis) in the available web sources.

However, I can tell you based on my knowledge that **SWARA** is a multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) methodology developed by Keršulienė, Zavadskas, and Turskis. It's a weighting method used in decision analysis where:

- **SWARA** stands for "Stepwise Weight Assessment Ratio Analysis"
- It's designed to determine the relative weights of decision criteria
- The method involves a stepwise process where decision-makers rank criteria and establish ratios between them
- It's particularly useful when you need to assign importance weights to different evaluation criteria in a decision-making problem
- The method has been applied in various fields including supplier selection, project management, and other multi-criteria decision problems

The method is an alternative to other weighting approaches like the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and is often used as part of larger MCDA frameworks.

If you need more specific information about SWARA's methodology, applications, or how it compares to other MCDM methods, I'd recommend consulting academic papers or specialized decision analysis literature, as detailed technical information about this specific method doesn't appear to be readily available in general web sources.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

   - Core concept underlying both SWARA and TOPSIS
   - Relation: Uses

   - Theoretical framework for the selection problem
   - Relation: Uses

   - Relation: Uses

   - Relation: Proposes
